awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CyberTraining: Pilot: Operationalizing AI/Machine Learning for Cybersecurity Training
awd_abstract_narration:
The interplay between AI and cybersecurity introduces new opportunities and challenges in the cybersecurity of AI as well as AI for cybersecurity. However, operations and configurations of AI cyberinfrastructure with a security mindset are rarely covered in the typical curriculum. To fill this gap, this project intends to develop hands-on training materials and provide mentored training for trainees in engineering and science-related disciplines. By transforming and integrating training materials into the curriculum, this project benefits the potential cyberinfrastructure professionals in the community at large. This project has the potential to develop the research workforce in operating AI cyberinfrastructure with a security mindset to meet national and economic priorities. 

This project’s goal is broadening adoption of advanced cyberinfrastructure. This project develops a holistic technical approach for cybertraining: to identify, apply, and evaluate AI techniques which are inextricably related to well-defined operational cybersecurity challenges. The project intends to develop a Docker-based training platform that simulates and pre-configures a variety of scenarios to support hands-on AI cyberinfrastructure operations in the context of cybersecurity. Three levels of projects (exploratory, core, and advanced) are designed and integrated into the platform to help researchers and educators customize and develop for different education and training environments. The project broadens the access and adoption of advanced AI cyberinfrastructure while integrating cyberinfrastructure skills with the security mindset to foster inter-disciplinary and inter-institutional research collaborations. In addition to dissemination through publications and social media, the outcomes from this project have the potential to benefit the greater cyberinfrastructure community and beyond. 

This project is jointly funded by OAC and the CyberCorps program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
This NSF-funded Cybertraining pilot project collaborated with the research team from the University of Maryland, Baltimore County, and focuses on the development of hands-on training for the current and future research workforce in operating AI cyberinfrastructure for cybersecurity. The training in this project is developed and organized using the Cyberinfrastructure clinic concept, in which the training logic is formulated in three stages, i.e., 1) identify why the problem is suitable for using AI techniques to resolve; 2) select and customize AI techniques for the problem; 3) implement and apply the AI techniques to solve the problem; and 4) evaluate the solution.  


Training and development opportunities: This project organized 12 weeks of training sessions as the pilot study. 20 participants from 12 universities were selected for the training, including undergraduate students, graduate students, and early-career faculty members. In addition, the design and development of training materials also inspire the research of graduate students at UMass Dartmouth, which has been expanded to the research in one PhD dissertation, two Master theses, two Master graduation projects, and one undergraduate research project at UMass Dartmouth. Training materials from this project were adopted by graduate-level courses at UMass Dartmouth to benefit more students. The materials were also shared with faculty members from non-project-team institutions to support the education and training of both undergraduate and graduate students.


Training resources: This project developed developed 9 training units for AI cyberinfrastructure in the context of cybersecurity, including cybersecurity background study, AI and machine learning background study, tutorials of AI cyberinfrastructure, time series analysis for cybersecurity, malware detection, network intrusion detection, scam/fraud detection, UAV anomaly detection, software vulnerability detection, and adversarial attacks against phishing websites. Materials from this project are also integrated into the book, AI for Cybersecurity: Research and Practice (ISBN 9781394293742). 


Program effects: The training program collects self-report pre- and post-surveys each year from training participants, using a 5-point Likert scale. The overall average ratings of the pre- and post-surveys indicate this training program significantly improved its participants' knowledge, skills, and operational capabilities of using AI cyberinfrastructure for cybersecurity. An exit interview was conducted for training participants by the project evaluator. Based on the interview and post-survey results, most participants acknowledged this training program provided very positive impacts to their career growth. In addition, the survey results also indicate the participants place a high value on AI and cybersecurity in their future academic and career goals and plans after completing the training.


Last Modified: 03/16/2025
Modified by: Jiawei Yuan
